newsitem.title: USA: NRC APPROVES RESTART OF PSE&G SALEM 2 NUKE.
newsitem.headline: NRC APPROVES RESTART OF PSE&G SALEM 2 NUKE.

text.p: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) said it has approved the restart of the 1,106 megawatt (MW) Salem 2 nuclear power plant, operated by Public Service Gas and Electric Co (PSE&G) of Newark, N.J.
"We've given a go ahead for Salem 2 to restart," an NRC spokesman said.
The unit, in Salem N.J., has been shut since 1995 for extensive upgrades after safety concerns at the facility were raised by the NRC.
Separately, a PSE&G official said Thursday the startup process began late Wednesday after they received a letter from the NRC giving them permission to put the unit back on line.

She said it would take the company about three to four weeks to bring the unit fully into service, citing the need for extensive testing as they ramp it back up to full power after such a lengthy outage.
The neighboring unit, Salem 1, also rated at 1,106 MW, is still on schedule to restart around the end of the year, she said.
Salem 1 also has been undergoing upgrades over the past two years to overcome safety concerns.
The Salem units are owned by PSE&G, Atlantic Energy Co in Egg Harbor, N.J., PECO Energy Co in Philadelphia, Pa., and Delmarva Power & Light Co in Wilmington, Del.
